verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD says: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.’"
verses.comment: The phrase ‘serve me’ is translated to convey both worship and service, as in the original Hebrew.

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go, then I will plague all your territory with frogs.
verses.comment: The specific threat is clear in the Hebrew: frogs as a widespread plague.

verses.text: The river will swarm with frogs, and they will come up and enter your house, into your bedroom, onto your bed, into the houses of your servants and your people, and into your ovens and kneading bowls.
verses.comment: ‘Swarm’ is a word-for-word rendering of the Hebrew yishretz. Physical locations are listed as in the original text.

verses.text: The frogs will come up on you, on your people, and on all your servants.’”
verses.comment: Maintains the threefold repetition found in Hebrew: ‘you, your people, your servants’.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, canals, and ponds, and make frogs come up over the land of Egypt.’"
verses.comment: Specific water sources listed per Hebrew: rivers, canals, ponds.

verses.text: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘Covered’ is a literal translation of the Hebrew kasah.

verses.text: But the magicians did the same by their secret arts, and made frogs come up on the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘Secret arts’ is literal for Hebrew latêhem (secret acts/magic).

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, "Pray to the LORD to take away the frogs from me and from my people, and I will let the people go to sacrifice to the LORD."
verses.comment: ‘Sacrifice to the LORD’ mirrors Hebrew le-zavach la-YHWH.

verses.text: Moses said to Pharaoh, "Specify when I should pray for you, for your servants, and your people, to destroy the frogs from you and your houses, so that they remain only in the river."
verses.comment: Moses offers Pharaoh choice of timing, per Hebrew 'Hitpaer'.

verses.text: He said, "Tomorrow." So Moses replied, "Let it be as you say, so that you may know that there is no one like the LORD our God."
verses.comment: ‘No one like the LORD’ reflects Hebrew uniqueness.

verses.text: The frogs will depart from you, your houses, your servants, and your people. They will remain only in the river."
verses.comment: Fourfold repetition matches original.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the LORD about the frogs which he had brought upon Pharaoh.
verses.comment: ‘Cried out’ rather than only ‘prayed’; original Hebrew verb.

verses.text: And the LORD did as Moses asked; the frogs died out in the houses, courtyards, and fields.
verses.comment: ‘Died out’ (Hebrew va-yamutu); ‘courtyards’ and ‘fields’ as listed.

verses.text: They gathered them together in heaps, and the land stank.
verses.comment: ‘Heaps’ and ‘stank’ are literal and vivid as Hebrew.

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and would not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: ‘Hardened his heart’ as literal Hebrew; matches prophecy.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the earth, so that it may become gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.’"
verses.comment: ‘Gnats’ for Hebrew kinnim; could mean lice or mosquitoes, but ‘gnats’ is standard.

verses.text: So they did so. Aaron stretched out his hand with his staff and struck the dust of the earth, and there were gnats on man and beast. All the dust of the earth became gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘On man and beast’ follows exact order of original text.

verses.text: The magicians tried with their secret arts to bring forth gnats, but they could not. So there were gnats on man and beast.
verses.comment: Clearly renders magicians’ failure.

verses.text: Then the magicians said to Pharaoh, "This is the finger of God." But Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: ‘Finger of God’ as literal Hebrew expression, meaning divine power.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Rise up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh as he goes out to the water. Say to him, ‘This is what the LORD says: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.’"
verses.comment: Translation retains command to rise early, matching original sequence.

verses.text: If you do not let my people go, I will send swarms of flies on you, your servants, your people, and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians shall be full of swarms of flies, and also the ground they stand on.
verses.comment: ‘Swarms of flies’ translates Hebrew arov, which implies harmful, biting flies.

verses.text: But on that day I will set apart the land of Goshen, where my people live, so that no swarms of flies will be there. This will happen so you may know that I am the LORD in the midst of the land.
verses.comment: ‘Set apart’ for Hebrew hiphlé; Goshen’s protection emphasized.

verses.text: I will make a distinction between my people and your people. Tomorrow this sign shall happen.’"
verses.comment: ‘Distinction’ is literal for Hebrew pedut.

verses.text: And the LORD did so. Dense swarms of flies came into the house of Pharaoh, his servants' houses, and through all the land of Egypt. The land was ruined because of the swarms of flies.
verses.comment: ‘Ruined’ (Hebrew shachat); swarms described as ‘dense’ as in context.

verses.text: Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, "Go sacrifice to your God within the land."
verses.comment: ‘Sacrifice to your God within the land’ preserves Pharaoh’s compromise offer.

verses.text: But Moses said, "That would not be right, for the offerings we sacrifice to the LORD our God are an abomination to the Egyptians. If we sacrifice what is abominable to the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us?"
verses.comment: ‘Abomination’ keeps the theological and cultural meaning of Hebrew to'evah.

verses.text: We must go a three-day journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the LORD our God, as he commands us."
verses.comment: ‘Three-day journey’ follows the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Pharaoh said, "I will let you go to sacrifice to the LORD your God in the wilderness; only do not go very far away. Plead for me."
verses.comment: ‘Plead for me’ is literal for Hebrew hitpa'el from ‘pray/intercede.’

verses.text: Moses said, "As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the LORD, and tomorrow the swarms of flies will leave Pharaoh, his servants, and his people. But let Pharaoh not deceive us again by refusing to let the people go to sacrifice to the LORD."
verses.comment: ‘Not deceive us again’ matches Hebrew verb for ‘act deceitfully.’

verses.text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Prayed’ is literal, as in Hebrew ‘va-yetar.’

verses.text: And the LORD did as Moses asked; he removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people. Not one remained.
verses.comment: ‘Not one remained’ (Hebrew: ‘lo nishar echad’).

verses.text: But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also, and did not let the people go.
verses.comment: Consistent with earlier ‘hardening of heart’ language in Exodus.
